column14: Notes
Dry, windmill off and not operational. By the rodeo grounds at Birdsprings
Behind the previous entry. Likely a surface seasonal source
Collected from basin due to trough being frozen. LO. Basin only had approximately an inch of water within it, but water was still able to be collected from the trough.
LO. Has a yellowish tinge to the water. On a hill across from the Black Mesa Chapter House
Drive down wash, look for grove of tamerisks just north of that. Collected directly from well. Handpump, vehicle access, and trough all available and operable. Tire and footprints suggests some use

North of Tuba City turn-off. Behind a church tank semi-visible from road. Location and vehicle tracks suggestion regular use. Pump gas generator that is only hooked up as needed. Water sample collected from tank directly. Sheen on surface of water.
Collected from trough. Number of cattle in the area w/ signs cattle walked in trough. Windmill on hill not far from trough
Dry. Locked gate; no access to sample water. Potentially muncipal NTUA.
Above Gap, from water sprout. LO
Collected from under cliff face, water in pump was frozen
Collected from Men's Restroom
Site was pretty muddy, collected after rainfall
Site was muddy
Water collected from a trough. Numerous cow pats and scrap metal near the site. On the same road as Shallow Well and Pond 461
Water leve was low, had to lower flask into the well. Some cow pats near the well. A stamp on the well states 13 Aug 1934. On the same road as Pond 461 and 3K-331

Windmill prop secured/unable to move w/ chain cable. Does not appear to be working. Water collected from bottom of tank (potentially/from precip). Black humic appearing and decomposition smelling material in tank.
ATLAS NEW Deep well, rope with rusty pale next to well, water level low, date: 4/3/64, on left of 160 on way S to Kayenta

On the road from Many Farms to Kayenta, north of road. Behind a gate with horse designs on it, old corral visible from tank and windmill. Water collected from windmill spigot pumping up groundwater. Had to climb to the top of the tank. Marking on pump and iwnd suggests the windmill was installed 8 August 1957. At around Mile Marker 25/40km

Not sampled. Visible storage tank from road and across from 8K-443, behind a hate. Driving down road reveals private well and separate tanks for complex of homes. Need to make contact in order to sample. Tanks and homes up against Mesa (second Mesa backside?) possible different groundwater source

Not sampled/Closed. Down the road from 7H-63. Faded sticker that tells water is not esafe to drink. Also spray painted warning "No hauling water./" Obvious smell of decomposition. Holes pierced in bottom of the tank. Windmill disconnected despite still pumping./

On the first visit there was no water to collect - the site was dry Collected water from the reservoir, but water was pumping directly into the reservoir. Likely that the in-flow pipe was not close to the hatch
LO. Very colorful painted cistern right off main road (161). Collected from vehicle hauler
On Indian Route 8077, turnoff next to Tselie Dine college. Visible from road. Collected from primary tank for car access that drains into cistern
Dry. Visible from road, Indian Route 8077. Windmill broken with line disconnected trough removed.
Collected from Silver tank. Visible from road going to Tsalie
Right off of main dirt road. Collected form trough. Winmill pumping, tank full, and overflow flowing into collection pond.
Dry. Disconnected windmill (no windmill, right off 191 North of Chinle)
Collected from trough. Cows and horses around windmill. Right next to the airstrip in Chinle
Dry. Missing windmill motor and props. Marked for LO. Tank dented and battered
ATLAS Surrounded by thorny bushes, no direct road, reach through wash, water from well, water levels low

Informed by local on 19 Jan 13 that the water had been very low that year. On second visitation: ATLAS Cameron Chapter Project No 3-3-10, date: 9/24/63, water level low, water from well, motor nearby for hand pump (not in use), nearby sign that is not very visible stateing that the water is not safe to drink
Low water level in tank. Windmill pumping and uncapped w/in tank, but no water coming out (dry) Water at bottom of tank, which was collecting
Collected from trough with floater
Near brick enclosure and near house/home
From trough. Nearby livestock, horses.
Near large cow fence. Stagnant water
Flowing water
Brown water, filters still clean. Rapid flowing water
Pond, copious amounts of vegetation around the pond. Sulfurous odor from the pond. Open pit that is exposed to the elements. On the same road as 3K-331 and Shallow Well
ATLAS NEW Closed, no longer in service, well is capped
ATLAS NEW Almost impossible to get to, after getting on right side of the mesa road turns sandy and difficult to drive on withouth getting stuck. Road looks like it is not regularily used.
Unable to Find
Dry. At border of wash. Turn North down wash to reach Clay Well
Drive about 2 miles down wash, on the left. No hand pump present. Likely not used as water source. Had to scoop water from bottom of well; open at the top so may be collecting rain water.
Have to walk to site, over sand dunes. Collected from handpump. Not in hauling use. Marked placard about uranium exposure.
Dry. Empty "NNWR" (Predecessor to NTUA) Tank at Blackfalls crossroads
Frozen. LO
From windmill spigot
From trough. LO. There is a story of two girls drinking the water and dying shortly after
From trough. LO
Going towards the Coppermine Chapter House. Frozen during Spring Break 2014 collection. LO
LO. From road past Greasewood Springs that says "Ranch" before turn. Take a right at the top and follow for 2 miles. Bees made a nest in the trough, water collected from the tank.
Collected from the bottom of the basin. There was rust, paint chips, and trash floating in the water
Just off the main road between Greasewood Springs and Steamboat. The stone basin is beautifully painted. Collected from trough
Off of the main road between Greasewood Springs and Steamboat. Collected from trough

Collected from trough. On second visitation noted that the tank read "Water is not safe to drink" LO. On third visitation there is new writing on the tank that claims the water is clean to drink and is "100% free of contaminants" as per EPA
Collected from trough. Far off of main road, approximately 10-15 minutes of off road travel to get to
Natural Spring
Collected from a hand pump Stamp with date: 9/11/64
ATLAS NE Spring feeds small stream and murky pond (water from pond), cows drinking from and bathing in pond. Unable to reach from Donnehotso, come in from Cane Valley. Meaning: Blank Shoe
ATLAS NEW Well near area closed, groundwater in area being monitored
NEW Site name very faint on tank, water from trough, water already in trough
NEW Area mostly stone, tank low to almost empty, water from trough, near phone lines

Not sampled. Tank empty. Appears windmill blades have been destroyed. Motor/pump and winmill have been locked. Perhaps that is what destroyed the blades. Out ofuse for a very ;long time. Observation: All of the windmills are on the north/northwest side of the road, as you get closer to Many Farms water becomes scarce.
Hand Pump
Across from Andee Lister's House Windmill

column1: Uncovered Water Well Behind NTUA - Dilkon
column14: LO
LO, No sample collected, water not available.
Handpump below the Dilkon Church. Just past it going east, turn down dirt road right near the bridge. First right past the "Dilkon Bible Church"

On second visit, the water level was pretty low so we had to use a weight in order to collect the water. Water smelt of manure and there was a bird carcass within the bucket that was inside the well. Numerous cow pats nearby. LO
Road to access ASON is on road between Winslow and Dilkon

Water collected from trough spigot. There was a vehicle hauler, but too long to utilize. Tank in view of both avenues of water access. Thank open to the environment (hatch ripped off). Water stagnant w/ a scum layer on the surface of the water. Water very red in color. No much water available (dry season?), requires standing on tank to get water to flow.

Came from 17T-540 backroads. Main road to this point accessible from GPS coordinates (35.52761, -109.86132 +/- 9). Collected from windmill to tank directly (climb on top). Come in from the road across "Greasewood Springs" Water Tower
In Whitecone, as if going towards 7H-63. Middle of grassland. Water collected from w/in the tank (you can climb inside)
Mostly for human consumption
Away from Coyote Springs near the road. Potentially this site feeds into the other site. Actually in a wash with a vehicle hauler
Collected from trough. LO. Dry on second visitation to the site
Closed, no sample collected
Frozen
Covered and empty, no water in basin. Still dry on second visit
LO
LO
Brought in from Andee from the Windowrock Area. All samples collected directly from a sandstone spring source
Brought in from Andee from the Windowrock Area. All samples collected directly from a sandstone spring source
Collected from trough. LO. Across the wash from the Greasewood Springs Chapter House
Collected from basin. LO. On second visitation there has been an automatic pump installed due to the windmill no longer working. There were a lot of livestock, cows, at the site on the second visit
Near Mae Kee Residence. LO
Up the road from 17T-522. Follow the road until you see road to follow poer lines. Will join up with the main road eventually.
Water collected from the tank itself, climbed pipe to the top. Completely full of water. Water appears clear. Trough nearby with a bladder floaty.
Not Sampled. Both underground concrete wells were empty and full of debris. Side of road, road to it looks like it has been washed out.
Broken, no water
Broken, not operational
Not operational

Tucked up against a hill. On backroad going towards Whitecone. On second vistation there was a new tank installed with a sign posted that strongly discourage residents to haul water from the tank, although it was still possible
Middle of a plain. On second visitation the windmill appeared to be broken and required a new component. Locals said until it is repaired they are driving to the chapter house to get water
Collected directly from windmill. Basin and trough empty - Low Water and/or frozen. On second visitation windmill pipes appeared to be rusted and were leaking water
Well Shut Down. Behind "Road Closed" Sign
LO. Always on
Below residential area, next to some cliff dwellings. Have to walk down to site
On the left side of church, park at the bottom of hill and follow small foot path that hugs canyon wall. Collected from pipe that flows into canyon
Dry, thick metal casing cap. On second visitation the hatch was found to be open and the basin had since been filled with debris with smell of decomposition and feces
Stream next to the picnic area above Keams Canyon and Low Mountain, on the background connected them that runs over the mesa. On second visitation there was no water in the basin or stream.
Collected from vehicle hauler. Marked as "Unregulated Water Source. Not Recommended for human consumption."

Opened to the elements, collected from a pond at the bottom of a depression/hole behind a chain linked fence surrounding the hole. Very rusty in color, stagnant, water filtrates up from the ground according to locales. Water remains murky after filtration. Compared to March, the water is very green (algae).

Locales said that the previous week (week of 9 March 14) unmarked vehicles arrived and tore down the windmill, resevoir tanks, and all water features. They pointed at another way to get to the water source, but required moving brush and boards. Mud steps led down to shallow mud area where water could be collected. Appeared almost like a tomb. On second visitation the water level appeared to be much higher, possibly more rain?
Regulated source, good to compare to non-regulated sources. On second visitation, two samples collected: one from the male restroom and one from the female restroom
Regulated source, good to compare to non-regulated sources. Pulled from the male bathroom

Regulated source, good to compare to non-regulated sources. EPA states that public water supplying the Hopi lands is in violation of As MCL with levels averaging 15-16ppb, and has been known for the past 15-20 years
Disconnected, no water in basin

Hopi Elders: Vern Mansfield and Larson Bahnimptewa, allowed us to get water and accompanied us showing us which waters they wanted tested. There was another spring within the canyon, but they said it is harder to get to and it was approaching sunset
Hopi Elders: Vern Mansfield and Larson Bahnimptewa, allowed us to get water and accompanied us showing us which waters they wanted tested.
Hopi Elders: Vern Mansfield and Larson Bahnimptewa, allowed us to get water and accompanied us showing us which waters they wanted tested.
Hopi Elders: Vern Mansfield and Larson Bahnimptewa, allowed us to get water and accompanied us showing us which waters they wanted tested.
Collected from the caf‚ bathroom

Old pump (#170593) stopped working. Collected from trough, pump down in the valley below run off of a solar powered pump. On second visitation collected from overflow trough within the cow pen. When driving down the dirt road, look for the "S" post on the road for the turn-off: S = Scott
Handpump next to road. It is on the right side of the road going east from USPHS 757, you will pass a broken down vehicle hauler go past that and go to the handpump
Collected from well covered by wooden plank. Old well tucked right up against the hill. Hard to visualize from road. There is a main road that runs right up to pump.
Right off of Rt 77 near Indian Wells. On third visitation noted that the basin tank had a fresh coat of the beige paint, has the water source become regulated?
Deep in the wash
Andee's Car Victory, On second visitation no water was collected
Water hauling station
No sample collected
From trough
Publically endorsed at the chapter house. Many wasps
Collected from trough. Dry on second visitation
Past the log house. Off of the main road to the north, east from Jeddato Chapter house (but on opposite hill). Look for Blue tire post on main road
Broken, does not appear to be in regular use. Water collected from the bottom of the basin
Brought in samples from Marsha from Northern Steamboat
Brought in samples from Marsha from Northern Steamboat
Pump disconnected. No water
Collected from trough
Collected from pipe that was drilled into the sandstone
Collected from trough
Lots of horses wating for water, water from trough, windy, sandy
Small pond near "Main Spring" water source, in Tsegi Canyon
Small pond near "Main Spring" water source, in Tsegi Canyon
Dry
East of Anasazi Inn, Covered, Clean
From trough. Near the tour shack (have to pass the tour shack) and past the Navajo Generating Station/Near the Powerplant
From windmill spigot. LO. Behind a locked cattleguard

North of Page on the west side of the road going towards Shonto. Visible from the road, about 1/4 mile from the road behind a gate. Next to a tree and a wash. Open to the environment, water likely just stagnant rain catch. On second visitation, the well was dry
Across the road from 1K-220, approximately 1.0 mile from the main road.

Collected from cow trough on first visitation. On second visitation both the tank and trough had the same pH. On second visitation, there appears to some additions from UA and the Renewable Energy Network and AZ engineering Solar Desalination Pilot Project. Samples collected from trough (post-production?) labeled "5T-529" from tank (Pre-Preduction?_ as pumping - labeled as "5T-529B" sensor w/in tank that turns on/off pump depending on water level
Collected from covered well. Local (Benson Willie) informed us that the well had been selected for radiation and uranium testing
Frozen on first visitation. On second visit the water is not frozen. Visible from right up the road from Box Springs. Collected from overflow spilling out.

Behind the Leupp Farm. Collected from open top tank with debris floating. Greenish color. Could hear water pumping, but could not get tanks working. Saw someone driving in as we were leaving going to haul water.
Just east of Leupp, visible from road collected from vehicle access
Visible on east side of road going from Leupp to Winslow. Collected from fulltank w/ windmill pumpinh
Visible on west side of road going to Winslow from Leupp. Directly west of "5T-526" collected from clean overflow
Right off road to Flagstaff from Leupp. Across from El Paso gas. Collected from trough windmill working.
Collected from trough. Not visible from main road, but right off behind a hill. Right off dirt road. Turn at church sign
Across sign from "Church of the Round Rock." Solar powered pump. Collected from top of the tank
Solar powered pump. Collected from trough. Lots of cows around.

Natural spring with waterfall outlet on the side of BIA13. Path can take you up the hill to chase source into the rocks. Well worn tire and footprints suggests regular use. Cleaned up copious amounts of refuse in area

Collected from vehicle hauler on rodeo grounds. Windmill with two tanks on hill above. Possible source, but waterlines visible in other parts of the community. Stamp suggests that the vehicle hauler was put in July 1976. Windmill still pumps and tank (connected) has water in it. Possibly connected to NTUA line?

On hill east of Dinnehotso. Look for Billboard on North side of roading advertising a ranch. May 0.5 miles east on north side after climbing up hill. Follow main dirt road. Water collected from trough with a pretty full tank.

Backroads just south o f Lukachukai. Turn right at bottom of hill if going towards Tselie or at Power Pylons. Obvious side of road 2 miles down dirtroad. Marked for LO. Completely full collected from trough
Dry. Continue on backroad from 11K-252 West of Lukachukai. Dismantled and dry. Windmill motor and props completely gone
Dry. Visible from road, between Lukachukai and Round Rock. Small motor, pump disconnected and trough gone.
Behind two gates. Tank full and windmill operational, but tied up. Possible private well - owned by "The Claws"
Go through fences, but on main road. Trough downhill approximately 0.25mi from windmill and tank. Met land owner named Agnes Tso, mother is Connie Tso and is the actual land holder.
Right off of a main dirt road. Collected from trough. Windmill active and pumping into stone tank
Collected from trough. Livestock present, horses
Neglected to get a pH reading of the water initially
From trough. Locals still use this water source, frequently. Second collection not from trough, but from raised basin
From trough, constantly runs. Collected from stone collection structure

Collected from vehicle hauler. Locales have repaired this well numerous times because NTUA keeps disconnecting it. These same locales report that the water is "crystal clear and cool", but really bad for the crops
Tucked behind, not visible from the road. Tanks spilling out water. Look for burn pile on main road in order to turn up to the water source
Collected from natural waterfall, but source is tucked into the rocks
Collected from trough. Horses at the trough. Second collection the water source was dry
Not regulated by NTUA or Navajo EPA, but local chapter requested that a filtered pump be added that was separate from trough. Second collection the water source was dry/shut off
Brought in from Andee from the Windowrock Area. All samples collected directly from a sandstone spring source
Collected from trough. LO. Second collection from the windmill spigot
Pasting "Goulding's". Sampled by the Army Corps of Engineering, near abandoned Uranium mine
Trough not working, sampled from large basin with open hatch
Piping tapped directly sandstone with it being directly feed into the trough. Piping runs through some type of filtration system
Possibly connected to same underground water source. Piping and tubing at this site allows run to freely drain constantly. Flow very slow with visible algae collecting in basin below and on tubing
Collected from trough. On the side of the mesa where heavy uranium mining occurred in the past
Collected from a hand pump. Water source is located on the edge of a mesa that over looks Monument Valley
Film on the surface of the water, indication for stagnation
Collected from a pond near the water source that was pointed out by Tommy Rock
Completely dry, only sand within the basin
Collected from a handpump
Collected directly from the well
Collected directly from the well
Collected from a hose that runs near a handpump near the post office of Goulding
NEW Hand pump, area seems isolated, but there are tire tracks, drive down wash
Collected from basin due to trough being frozen. LO. Dry on second visitation to the site
Well has been disconnected, likely by locales. LO
Dry despite the windmill working and the pump still operational. On second visitation there was some cracked mud at the bottom of the basin, possible suggestion of water?
Dry despite the windmill working and the pump still operational. Sand and debris in the bottom of the basin with an open hatch
Dry despite the windmill working and the pump still operational. Fine sand at the bottom of the basin
Dry, not pumping. Holes drilled into the bottom of the tank
Dry and hatch is weled shut.
Just east of Red Valley Chapter House. Visible from road, right at NM/AZ Border
Marked in Atlas as #22. Handpump located in wash at bottom of hill. Old USPHS Well. Dry
Handpump handle removed and road to pump has been covered and gated chained. Resembles PHS pumps, but no visible stamp. Hard to visualize from road.

On maintained dirtroad. New cistern net to old cistern. Trough has new yellow valve. Access is across road going towards Cove. Obvious dirtroad. New Cistern full,. Can actively hear water at source from ground. Old cistern empty.
Collected from trough
Collected directly from the sandstone, in Tsegi Canyon

On road from Many Farms to Kayenta. Near Rough Rock Turnoff. Visible from road. Many cows near tank. Low water level in tank despite windmill going. Climbed on top of the tank to get sample. While sampling location a number of people with water tanks drove by. Perhaps they are hauling water from elsewhere?

On road from Many Farms to Kayenta. North side of the road, many cows nearby when sampling. Gas pump nearby, but windmill still operational . Collected from white tank marked for LO. Had to shimmy over water pipe to sample. Trough plugged
Visible from road between Lukachukai and Round rock. Most of secondary structures gone, but pump and windmill still working. Cistern made of stone.
Dry. Visible from road between Round Rock and Manyfarms. Follow Power Poles to get to site. Despite Windmill pumping site dry. Open tank, wet mud within cistern --> Not dried?water recently?

Collected from trough. On third visitation accompanied by locals from the area, they stated that they are not sure if anyone still uses this particular water source. They did not state why they had that opinion
Collected from trough. Tucked behind hill, not visible from the road
Collected from trough
Collected from trough
No water despite the windmill pumping and working
Collected from trough
Completely dry, vehicle hauler connected to tank
Collected from trough, at the top of a hill
From trough. Above Shonto, drive along dirt road until you see a "stop sign" and then turn at the sign
Water is clear, families and locals state that they regularly use this water. It is a natural spring right up against the mountains just north of Shonto. It is south of Windmill "2T-504"

The coordinates to drive into are at (36.86271, -110.60874). Follow the road until you come to a wash bed. Follow the wash until you come up to a cliff wall. If the water is plentiful then there should be a waterfall coming down the rocks. If the water is not plentiful, you need to climb the rock face to the water source. The water is coming from a groundwater source the seeps up from the ground
Water source open to the elements
Resident, Earl Edison, states that the site is known to be high in lead
LO

LO, not covered/exposed to the elements. Local says that this well is known to exceed some drinking water limits set by both the USEPA and NNEPA. On second visitation the water level was extremely low and there was a lot of horses near the trough. Looking at the windmill pump it appears that the windmill has been disconnected and likely the water within the basin is just rain catch. On third visitation: Noted a warning sign posted on the tank telling about quality of the water. Windmill has been chained in place to prevent pumping. Motor closed. Open to the environment, w/ stuff floating in it. Quite certain water in there is rain catch
Windmill not operating, collected from basin. Unchained area and uncovered
Brought in samples from Marsha from Northern Steamboat
Brought in samples from Marsha from Northern Steamboat
Brought in samples from Marsha from Northern Steamboat
Dry. Posted warning stating that the water is not safe for consumption
Collected from trough. Livestock present, horses
All water features (trough, basin, pumps) dry. The ground was moist and saturated with water however. Soil sample collected
Stamp on the well feature notes that it was constructed 12 June 1914. Water was collected from a nearby pond that collected run off.
Collected from a windmill on the property of an elderly woman living near Snake Canyon
Collected from trough. Livestock present, horses
Collected from trough
Visible from road just up from Cottonwood Chapter going towards Pinon. Very full,. Water leaking from bottom of tank from a small hole.
Dry. On slope against hill, above residence. Visible from road going to Blue Gap plainly mark for LO. Windmill working and pumping but no water.
Visible from road, turn-off into maintained gravel road. Cistern painted Periwinkle. Locals drove up and said it is "Good water."

Visible/right next to road. Two tanks only larger and newer beige tank hooked up. Despite windmill working, very little water in cistern (Dry season). Have to climb to the top of the tank and lower rope to get sample.
Collected from trough and tank right next to Blue Gap Chapter House. No visible windmill, but stone structure next to tank?possible pump? Labeled as unregulated.

Name so because everything happened twice with the two: two troughs, two croded holes, twice hooked up to a windmill. Visible at a distance from road to Blue Gap. Go down maintained dirt-pathh to N/S maintained gravel road.

Road very rocky, have to hike to spot. Not visible from road and hidden behind large boulder. Follow cords until you see path go up toward slope/hill. To your right should be small valley. Climb down and look for water and water access on opposite wall.
Collected from steep run off next to abandoned mine. Had to dig shallow depr4ession to allow water to pool before collection

Park at (36.293351, -109.831032). The spring is aon opposite canyon wall. You have to climb down the canyon to the spring. Appears spring seeps up from the ground and pours over the rocks. There was a dead cow at the site
Collected from spigot on the well basin
Collected from a spigot that was near the well
Not Sampled/Dry. Appears use to be a cistern with a trough, now replaced with a municipal tank

Follw road from Highway 61/64 for about 1-2 miles. Right next to dirt road. Near Tec Nex Pos. Markings on trough suggest new trough put in 18 Jul 13. Collected from trough, allowed to run. Go down road 9040

Collected from trough. Hard to visualize from road. Behind old abandoned house, but newer house/property further back. Fresh truck tradcks suggest regular use. No significant markings. Above Tec Nes Pos. Cistern quite full. Not too far before 12T-517 ---> Down road 9035

On top of mesa going towards Shiprock before turnoof for 12T-517 or 9T-591. Turn at Little Dipper Flag. Windmill near houses. Collected from trough. Water intially brown before becoming clear. Passed marked water line. Perhaps serves the house?

Collected by Drs. Browder and Koppisch when they traveled to relatives over the winter holidays in 2017. Was collected and stored in an HDPE Centrifuge tube until delivered to the laboratory. Once in the laboratory it was placed on the shaker table for six hours to resuspend solids, then filtered, acidified, and stored. Based on the location, it is likely a regulated/PWS source.

Stagnant water, w/in brick structure. On second visitation, samples were pulled both from the vehicle hauler and the brick building. On fourth visitation, the sample was collected from the vehicle hauler
Collected from trough. On second vistation the windmill was no longer operational and no sample was collected
Frozen. On second visitation the water source was not frozen and a sample was collected
Tucked up against a hill. Collected from vehicle hauler. On second visitation the well was dry and no water available.
Frozen
Source of water for Chapterhouse
Water pump outside of school, side of road
Collected from trough
Collected from trough
Collected from trough
On the backroads towards Inscription House coming from Tuba City

Behind utility gate, had to walk across field to access. Trough pump not operational. Windmill stillintact and cistern full. Water bright green and viscous. Felt very slimy and very hard to filter. LO

South of Wheatfields Lake. Take dirtroad at bend before going towards stateline/countyline. Middle of large prarie. LO. Open air cistern w/ two drains for overflow. Cistern full and at angle. Water green.

Sample collected from free flowing pipe. Locales labeled this site as a spring although there is a tank present. Climbing the tank and looking in revealed it full, perhaps overflow? No shut-off valve present. Locales the day before seen gathering water - regular use. In forests behind wheatfields, off of maintained gravel road. Look for turnoff w/ lots of sand/wide and obvious turnoff.
On road from Chinle to Tsalie. Visible from road. Collected from trough
Closed
Dry. Visible from road between Chinle and Pinon. Small motor/ large prop windmill. Still pumping no water. Closed top tank that is completely dry inside.
Dry. Visible from road at cottonwood chapter. Posted and faded EPA warning. "This water is not safe to drink". Windmill props and pump still functional, no water. Opened top tank that is dry

LO. Right across the road from the chapter house at cottonwood. Locals seen filling up and hauling water here, say they do so quite frequently. Note that sometimes the water that comes out of it the animals will not drink. They are not sure why this is the case, they have never tried the water itself. They say that they will only drink the clean water from the chapter house. Visible from the road, just up from 10R-518. One of the locals was the Chapter President at Blue Gap, knows Tommy Rock...of course
Collected from Employee's Restroom
Public Well
Tommy says that he knows this to be a shallow well source. Collected from flowing pipe
Standing Water, slightly turbid
Collected from flowing water source
Collected from water trough. Nearby livestock, cows. On second visitation, the water was collected directly from the well, water appeared stagnant, and cows were present
Turbid (required two filters). One mile north of US 160, off road to the north from the road. Well identified as having alpha emitters
Collected from pipe. Livestock (cows) present
No water collected from pipe. Up a hill off of the main road. The whole area is developed with electricity and running water. The area surrounding the pump is full of liter

Go down the road towards "Dinosaur Tracks." Continue until the T-Intersection at the base of Mesa and turn left. The spigot is in front of the Hoogan at the Y-Fork. Water appears clean and clear and the spigot head is of new brass
Attempted to find, area had water but no public water source. Here is a pump but it looks like it has not been used in some time. Two fenced yards nearby (likely similar water source)
No water available. Looks abandoned, but there is a vehicle hauler
Dry despite the windmill working and the pump still operational. On second visitation the windmill pump has been cut and disconnected
Collected from trough. Visible from BIA 4. In middle of Valley w/ many homesteads w/in Valley. Two tanks, now pumping into never beige tank. LO
Marked Livestock Only (LO)
Water is used for LO and personal human consumption. Water collected from pipe coming directly out of the ground. Has been used for two generations.
On road from Many Farms to Kayenta, west north west side of the road. Across from NHA Housing and regulated water. Number of small homesteads on this grasslands plains

One possible route is to come in from road directly south of the well (~3miles). Will drive by a lone Red House on the Priaire. Well/Windmill tucked far in the hills, not visible from the road. Water collected directly from the feeder pipe (windmill to the tank). Climbed on top and there is a corroded hole you can collect the water from.
Spring water source pools into underground well. Behind someone's residence. Labeled on Atlas as "Whitecone Spring" Crank for handpump was removed

Tucked behind many hills. Local was getting/hauling water from trough. Handpump against the hill non-functional. "Department of Water Resources" on the side of the trough. Local said he has been drinking the water for "a long time?it is good water."
